Invited Talk 20 Years of Industrial Functional Programming Ulf Wiger Ericsson AB Älvsjö, Sweden ulf.wiger@ericsson.com 
 Abstract It is now 20 years since the Ericsson Computer Science Laboratory (CSLab) was formed, and 20 
years since CSLab started performing the programming language experiments that eventually led to the 
development of the Erlang programming language. For 15 years, Ericsson has conducted experiments with 
Erlang in an industrial setting, and for 12 years, actual commercial products have been developed. This 
talk summarizes some of the lessons learned from this work. It is well known that it is difficult to 
introduce a new programming technology. Even so, engineers often fail to realize that the reasons for 
resisting change are more often social/political than technical, even though the objections may seem 
technical in nature. This talk will highlight a few of the common objections to Erlang, and measure them 
against practical experience. In addition, it will suggest some topics for research that could result 
in significant cost savings in the near future, as well as inspire closer cooperation between industry 
and academia. Bio Ulf Wiger is a Senior Software Architect in the IP Connectivity and Control Nodes Department 
at Ericsson AB. He was Chief Designer of the Ericsson AXD 301 Multi-Service Gateway, a key component 
in Ericsson s market-leading Packet-based Telephony solution. With more than 2 million lines of Erlang 
code, AXD 301 is one of the largest systems ever written in a functional language; with better than 99,999% 
service availability around the clock, it is one of the most robust, and with more than 1,000 systems 
delivered to all continents and a position as market leader, it is also one of the most commercially 
successful. Copyright is held by the author/owner(s). ICFP 04, September 19 21, 2004, Snowbird, Utah, 
USA. ACM 1-58113-905-5/04/0009. 162
